history.content:
Just to put it out there, you don't have to officially have a math minor in order to take math classes. If you feel like you have a good foundation in what Math 1b will teach (techniques of integration, series, some diff eqs) then you should probably test out of it to take more meaningful math classes later on. Taking an upperdiv math class might also help you decide if you want to officially declare the math minor as well.

---------------------

From a more logistical perspective, if you're interested in testing out of some of these classes, it's probably best to talk to your EECS / Math advisers, since you generally have to petition for these things.  For reference, I was able to petition out of 53 for both the EECS and Math majors because I took an equivalent class in high school--EECS made me take an upper division math class in its place, and Math made me take the 53 final exam.  I don't think this is very common, but it certainly wouldn't hurt to ask your ESS adviser about it.

Just to put it out there, you don't have to officially have a math minor in order to take math classes. If you feel like you have a good foundation in what Math 1b will teach (techniques of integration, series, some diff eqs) then you should probably test out of it to take more meaningful math classes later on. Taking an upperdiv math class might also help you decide if you want to officially declare the math minor as well.

Just to put it out there, you don't have to officially have a math minor in order to take math classes. If you feel like you have a good foundation in what Math 1b will teach (techniques of integration, series, some diff eqs) then you should probably test out of it to take more meaningful math classes later on.

Just to put it out there, you don't have to officially have a math minor in order to take math classes. If you feel like you have a good foundation in what Math 1b will teach (techniques of integration, series, some diff eqs) then you should probably test out of it to take more meaningful classes later on.

Hi there,

The only classes that CoE accepts "credit by exam" are Math 1A and Math 1B. I would suggest connecting with your ESS Adviser and the math department to discuss logisitics.

I have heard a lot about students testing out of certain courses they felt like they had sufficient knowledge in. I was wondering what the process for doing this looks like and what courses this is possible for. I'm an EECS major and interested in a math minor so for the most part interested in testing out of overlapping courses. Specifically I am mainly interested in testing out of: 

- Math 1B

- Physics 7A

- Math 54

Any advice? 

Edit: I know AP credits let you test out of 1B and 7A but my school didn't offer AP physics, and my AP calc score was a 4, which is enough for EECS but not math.
history.subject: Testing out of Courses
